segments.text: Hey everyone, welcome back to our next lesson on emotional mastery.
Last time in emotional mastery we talked about how moving your body, like fixing your posture
or taking deep breaths, can totally change your emotions and make learning English easier.
I mentioned there are two big ways to shift how you feel. We covered the first one, physiology
or using your body. Today we're jumping into the second one, your mental focus. That's all about
what you think about all the time because what's in your head can seriously change how you feel
and how fast you learn English. So what's mental focus all about? It's super simple. It's what you
choose to think about over and over again. And trust me, it matters a lot. So how do you switch
up your focus?
What should you think about? What should you not think about? Let's break it down. First,
let's talk about the negative stuff, what not to focus on. Picture this. You're back in school,
sitting in English class. What's in your mind all the time? What are you stressing about?
Probably tests, right? I've got to pass this test. What if I mess up? That was me too.
I was always frustrated.
Freaking out about tests. And then there's grades. Will I get an A? A B? Oh no. What if I fail?
You're worrying about what the teacher thinks, what score you'll get, how people will judge you.
Sound familiar? Or maybe now it's not school tests. It's something like the TOEFL exam.
You're thinking, what score will I get? Will it be good enough?
So how does that make you feel?
More chilled out or more stressed?
Yeah, probably stressed. And here's the problem. When you're all wound up about tests and scores,
you actually learn slower. Seriously. There's this expert doctor, Steven Krashen. He's a big
deal in language research. And he says anxiety is the number one enemy of learning a language.
When you're nervous, your brain just doesn't soak up English as well.
Think about it. Studies show that relaxed students after, say, six months, end up with better grammar, smoother pronunciation, sharper listening skills, and stronger writing.
But the stressed out ones, they struggle more with everything. Speaking, vocab, you name it.
Back in school, all that focus on tests and grades was basically training us to feel nervous and learn slower.
Crazy, right?
So let's agree to drop that test obsession now.
Another thing to skip? Don't get stuck thinking about every little step you need to take to get good at English.
Your big goal is awesome. Speaking English fluently, feeling strong and confident.
Love that. But what happens if you zoom in on every tiny thing you have to do?
Like, I've got to study every day, learn 20,000 words, listen to English for three days, and then I'm going to be able to do it.
I've got to study every day, learn 20,000 words, listen to English for three days, and then I'm going to be able to do it.
How does that feel?
Overwhelming, right?
It's like staring up at a giant mountain and thinking, I can't climb that.
It kills your motivation fast.
So no focusing on all those little steps. It's too much.
What else should you avoid?
Problems.
I bet some of you are thinking, my pronunciation's terrible.
Or, I keep messing up.
Grammar.
Okay, but here's the deal.
You're a student. That's normal.
You're learning, so of course you'll slip up sometimes.
Even me, a native speaker and teacher, I make mistakes all the time.
It's human.
If you keep obsessing over problems or mistakes, you'll just feel worse.
Your emotions tank, and guess what?
You get worse at English, so chill out about that stuff.
Everyone knows.
Everyone messes up, and it's all good.
One last no-no.
The past.
How many of you have bad memories of English class?
When I ask students about it, they're like,
Oh, it was awful. I'm terrible at English.
I studied for years and still can't speak.
Sound familiar?
But here's the truth.
The past doesn't matter anymore.
Back then, you were stuck with boring textbooks.
Constant tests and stiff classroom vibes.
Old school methods that didn't work for most people.
That's not how you're learning now.
You're doing it differently, and you're different now.
So, let's leave the past where it belongs.
Behind us.
Like Tony Robbins says, the past doesn't equal the future.
Totally true.
Okay, now the good stuff.
What should you focus on?
Enough of what to avoid.
Let's flip it.
What should you think about to feel excited, happy, and learn English faster than ever?
Here's the game plan.
Number one.
Focus on the end result.
Forget the little steps.
Dream about the big win.
Picture yourself speaking English like a pro.
Smooth, fast, and confident.
Imagine chatting with a native speaker smiling.
Imagine chatting with a native speaker smiling.
Feeling totally at ease.
Every day, take a second to see that in your head.
Like, close your eyes and think,
There I am rocking my English.
Killing it in a conversation.
That's your future, and it's awesome.
Keep your eyes on that prize, not the daily grind.
Number two.
Focus on your why.
Why are you learning English?
If your answer is, to pass a test.
That's no fun.
It just stresses you out.
Nobody gets hyped about a test.
You need a bigger, better reason.
Maybe you're taking the TOEFL, but why?
What's the real goal?
A killer job where you use English every day, like in international business?
Studying abroad at a cool university?
Living in an English-speaking country?
Picture yourself in New York or London, talking effortlessly with new friends.
Landing a sweet job with better pay?
Having epic travel adventures?
That's the stuff that fires you up.
So think about those big, exciting reasons.
Those benefits that make you feel alive.
Not some boring test.
Here's the trick.
You've got to imagine it vividly.
See that end result, speaking great English, and feel it like it's real.
Don't just think about it.
Get into it.
Feel proud.
Feel happy.
Feel confident.
Smile big while you're imagining it.
Let those good vibes sink in.
It's like a mental boost that keeps you going strong.
So, super simple.
Focus on the good vibes.
Good stuff.
Think about that end result, speaking amazing English and all the incredible things it'll
bring to your life.
New friends?
Epic travel?
A dream job?
Whatever gets you pumped.
Here's a cool idea.
Grab a notebook and write down a list of all the awesome things that'll happen when you're
fluent in English.
Make it big.
Dream wild.
Then, every day, read that list.
Let it sink in.
Teach your brain to lock onto these positive, inspiring things.
Not tests.
Not mistakes.
Not the past.
Alright, that's it for Emotional Mastery 2.
Focus.
You've got this.
Keep your head in the right place and you'll be amazed at how fast you improve.
Next up, we'll hit the vocabulary, then dive into the mini-story.
Can't wait.
Stay tuned.
